options: Explore the patients feelings and concerns further
Cancel the surgery
Explain to her that you will inform your senior
Contact the family and explain what the patient told you
Ask a cancer nurse specialist to come and talk with the patient
questions:
You are a junior doctor on the colorectal ward. One of the elderly patients on your ward is due to undergo surgery for a rectosigmoid carcinoma. On chatting with her, she confides that she feels pressurised by her family to go through with the surgery and she would rather die peacefully.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
A is ranked highest. It is important to explore why the patient is feeling this way. This will give you a better understanding of her situation and of any fears and concerns. This shows the patient you are taking her views seriously and allows you to tailor her ongoing care.

The ultimate decision as to whether she has the surgery will lie with your senior. Therefore it is important to pass on any views the patient has in regards to their surgery to someone higher up. it is however more important to gain a greater understanding as to why she is feeling this way hence option C is ranked lower than A.

B and D are both poor options. Although you are doing as the patient wishes, as a junior doctor it is not appropriate to cancel a surgery before consulting with the patient's consultant.

D is the worst option as it breaks patient confidentiality. The patient confided this information to you which implies that she felt she could not talk it through with her family. If anything, you should try to persuade her to speak to the family herself. There is no reason for you to speak with them without the patients consent and this breaks the patients trust in you.

options: Ask the patient to sign self-discharge paperwork
Detain the patient under the Public Health Act
Discharge the patient
Discuss the situation with the hospital legal team
Inform your consultant immediately
questions:
You are the F2 doctor working in the infectious disease ward. You are looking after a 45-year-old man with active pulmonary multi-drug resistant tuberculosis infection. He has issues with poor compliance with medications and is currently homeless. He is stable on 2L oxygen via nasal cannulae. You are called to see the patient as he would like to be discharged from the ward.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
The patient has an active multidrug-resistant TB infection. This is a major threat to public health. Patients with TB can be discharged early, if they are able to take their treatment correctly, and have their treatment monitored. However, in this case, the patient is homeless and has issues with compliance with medications. Therefore on the balance of the patient's rights versus the risk to public health, the scales tip towards protecting the public. In England and Wales, the power to detain individuals with tuberculosis who pose a threat to public health lies principally in sections 37 and 38 of the Public Health Act 1984.

The consultant should be informed immediately. They may be able to mediate the situation and encourage the patient to stay on their own accord. Good communication skills may result in the resolution of this issue. Explaining to the patient that his condition requires treatment as an inpatient due to the risk of harm to others and addressing any of their concerns would be paramount before further steps are made. Alternative options could include arranging suitable accommodation with the use of 'directly observed therapy'.

It would also be important to assess the patient's capacity. The Mental Capacity Act (MCA) sets out a 2-stage test of capacity:

  • 1. Does the person have an impairment of their mind or brain, whether as a result of an illness, or external factors such as alcohol or drug use?
  • 2. Does the impairment mean the person is unable to make a specific decision when they need to? Patients can lack the capacity to make some decisions but have the capacity to make others. Mental capacity can also fluctuate with time.

The MCA states that a person is unable to make a decision if they cannot:

  • Understand the information relevant to the decision
  • Retain that information
  • Use or weigh up that information as part of the process of making the decision

In this case, it would be useful for you to start the process of assessing capacity, however, a more senior doctor should repeat it before making a formal decision given the seriousness of the situation.

If considering detention under the Public Health Act, it would be essential to discuss with the hospital legal team prior to invoking. However, less invasive measures should be explored first, and the consultant in charge would be the best person to have these complex discussions.

Detaining under the Public Health Act is rarely required. However, if the patient is not agreeable to remaining an inpatient, then this would be a possibility following a discussion with the legal team.

Discharging the patient is clearly inappropriate at the moment. The patient is unwell with an oxygen requirement and so any possible discharge would need to be a 'self-discharge against medical advice' as the patient is not medically fit for discharge. However, self-discharge is still not a good option as it exposes others to TB and considerable risk.

title: Patients who refuse treatment
body:
Many patients who are admitted to hospital, or treated in the community, lack capacity. In the vast majority of cases, these patients do not refuse treatment that is given that is deemed to be in their best interest. The problem arises when patients who lack (or are suspected of lacking) capacity refuse treatment.

There are 3 main frameworks that are used in this scenario:
  • common law: used to treat patients in emergency scenarios
  • Mental Capacity Act: (MCA) used in patients who require treatment for physical disorders that affect brain function. Remember this may be delirium secondary to sepsis or a primary brain disorder such as dementia
  • Mental Health Act (MHA): used in patients who require treatment for mental disorders. For patients already admitted to hospital, a section 5(2) is used if there is not the time for a more formal section 2 or 3. A typical scenario would be a patient who has a mental health disorder attempting to discharge themselves, when it is thought this may result in harm

An excellent, more in-depth review can be found in the BMJ 'When and how to treat patients who refuse treatment'. BMJ 2014;348;g2043

options: Tell your colleagues about what happened in the mess to ensure they are aware of the doctors limitations
Say nothing, stay with the patient and take over when he asks for help
Go and get the A&E consultant
Say nothing at the time but fill in a clinical incident form
Immediately voice your concerns and ask him to stop
questions:
You are a F2 doctor in General Medicine. During an on-call you are in A&E seeing a patient who has a pneumothorax. On arriving you find the A&E ST2 doctor attempting to perform an aspiration. He appears to about to insert the needle at the wrong landmark.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
If you have concerns regarding the management of a patient it is important to act on them. It may be that you are wrong - the ST2 doctor may actually be performing the aspiration using a recognised, safe technique. This should not however stop you voicing your concerns - failing to do so may put the patient at risk.

If you feel unable to do you should discuss your concerns with someone who is in a position to act. Saying nothing puts the patient at potential harm. Filling in a clinical incident form after the event will not alter this.

Spreading rumours in the mess about a doctors ability is unprofessional and unlikely to lead to a resolution of the problem.

You are a ST1 doctor in the Emergency Department. A trauma patient is admitted to Resus and the Orthopaedic Registrar is called in from home. On arrival you can smell alcohol on his breath although he appears sober and focused.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The best response is to immediately contact the on-call consultant. As the patient may potentially require treatment overnight it is not acceptable to wait until the morning to report the matter.

Filling in a clinical incident form provides an official record of your concerns but does nothing to address the immediate problem.

Telling the registrar off at least recognises that there is a problem, but does not stop the patient being exposed to a potential risk.

questions:
You are working as a GP registrar. Your next patient is a 38-year-old woman with a history of bipolar disorder and alcohol dependence. Her main reason for attendance is to tell you she saw one of the other doctors looking at pornography on the internet whilst entering his room last week. She says he quickly closed the internet browser and no further mention was made of it.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
Her history of mental illness may mean she is more likely to make false allegations but this is not grounds for ignoring her claims. The patient should therefore be informed that you will look into the matter. The only practical way to refute the allegation is to examine the internet log of the doctor. Given the nature of the allegations the accused doctor should be informed - it may be that he would put a completely different light on the encounter.

Viewing pornography at work is unprofessional and may lead to dismissal but is not a police matter. The GMC do not need to be contacted at this stage.

options: Arrange teaching to highlight the importance of patient confidentiality
Go and find the colleague immediately
Ask another colleague what they would do in this situation
Inform your colleague he left the patient's notes on display
Escalate the incident to the information governance team
Close down the patient's notes
Log the colleague off the medical records system
Inform the patient their confidentiality has been breached
Inform the colleague's clinical supervisor about the incident
Leave the colleague's computer undisturbed
questions:
You come back from your lunch break to find that a colleague is logged into a ward computer. You notice that a patient's notes are open on the computer, detailing a conversation around consent for a blood test to check the patient's HIV status. You have not seen the colleague nearby and he has not returned to his computer for 15 minutes.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
In this scenario, the patient's confidentiality has been potentially put at risk as their notes have been left open where other staff members or even patients and family members can see them. The most appropriate action would be to ensure these patients' confidentiality is not broken. Thus closing down the patient's notes and logging the colleague off the medical records system form part of the correct answer. You should also inform your colleague he left the patient's notes on display so he is aware of this mistake and will be more mindful in the future.

Arrange teaching to highlight the importance of patient confidentiality would raise awareness around patient confidentiality but it is not one of the most immediate actions to consider. You must first deal with this specific scenario to prevent patient confidentiality from being compromised.

It is not appropriate to go and find the colleague immediately as this could prove timely and you have to be mindful of your own workload.

It is not appropriate to ask another colleague what they would do in this situation as this is a time-sensitive situation and you need to act promptly.

It is not appropriate to escalate the incident to the information governance team as you have not spoken to the colleague in question yet. Also, there is no evidence that patient confidentiality has been breached as of yet.

It is not your role to inform the patient their confidentiality has been breached as any patient discussions should be carried out by the colleague in question. And again, there is no evidence that patient confidentiality has been breached yet.

It is not appropriate to inform the colleague's clinical supervisor about the incident as you should always confront the colleague in the question in the first instance.

To leave the colleague's computer undisturbed is clearly incorrect as this risks the patient's confidentiality being compromised.

title: GMC guidance: Confidentiality
body:
The UK General Medical Council (GMC) provides guidelines on confidentiality to help doctors maintain trust with their patients and respect their right to privacy. Here is a summary of the key principles in GMC's guidance on confidentiality:
  • Patients' right to privacy: Doctors must respect patients' right to privacy and should not disclose their personal information without consent, unless required by law or justified by the public interest.
  • Obtaining consent: Whenever possible, doctors should obtain explicit consent from patients before disclosing their information. The consent should be informed and given freely, and patients should understand the potential consequences of sharing their information.
  • Anonymization: When using patient information for purposes such as teaching, research, or quality improvement, doctors should anonymize the data whenever possible to protect patients' identities.
  • Disclosures in the public interest: In exceptional circumstances, doctors may disclose patient information without consent if it is in the public interest, such as to prevent serious harm to others or in response to communicable diseases that pose a risk to public health.
  • Legal requirements: Doctors must comply with legal requirements to disclose patient information, such as court orders or statutory reporting obligations.
  • Confidentiality after death: Doctors should continue to respect patients' confidentiality even after their death, unless there are compelling reasons to disclose information.
  • Sharing information with the healthcare team: Doctors may share patient information within the healthcare team on a need-to-know basis to provide safe and effective care.
  • Record-keeping: Doctors should maintain accurate, up-to-date, and secure records to protect patient information and ensure its confidentiality.
  • Communicating with patients: Doctors should communicate openly and honestly with patients about their right to confidentiality and how their information may be used.
  • Working with third parties: When working with third parties, such as insurers or employers, doctors should ensure that they have appropriate consent from patients before sharing their information.

options: Tell them you already have a partner even if it is not true
Ask a colleague if he is able to take over this patient's care
Inform your consultant
Politely decline
Explain that it is inappropriate for you to date a patient
Continue with their care as normal
Accept the offer

questions:
You are a junior doctor working on the renal unit. A young 'frequent-flyer' patient whom you know well and have treated on numerous occasions beckons you over to his bedside. He tells you that he has been trying to pluck up the courage to ask for a while but would like to take you out on a date if you would agree to it. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
The most sensible decision in this scenario is to politely decline and explain why. There is guidance from the GMC surrounding intimate relationships with patients but as a general rule, if you are at the present time caring for that patient then you are in a position of trust and therefore should avoid it.

Accepting the offer is therefore not a good option (even if you pay for yourself!). Your consultant is unlikely to do much more than to advise you to decline the offer. Given the expressed romantic interest of the patient, it is appropriate for another doctor to take over their care.

title: GMC: Ending your professional relationship with a patient
body:
The GMC guidelines contain information on ending your professional relationship with a patient. They state that;

You must only end a professional relationship with a patient when the breakdown of trust means you cannot provide good clinical care. This includes the patient being violent, threatening you or being abusive or the patient having stolen from you or the premises. It also includes the patient persistently acted inconsiderately or unreasonably or if they have made a sexual advance to you.

You should not end a relationship due to a complaint or due to resource implications.

Before you end the relationship you must warn the patient you are considering ending it and do what you can to restore the relationship. If this fails you must explore alternatives to ending it and discuss the situation with an experienced colleague or your employer.

When you end a relationship you must be satisfied that your reason is fair and does not discriminate. Then make sure the patient is told this is happening, and why. If practical do this in writing.
concept: The GMC advise that as you are in a position of trust you should not start a relationship with a patient you have cared for

questions:
You are a ST1 doctor on a gastroenterology ward. The F2 doctor has asked you to supervise him putting in an ascitic drain for a patient with liver cirrhosis. He is keen to get it signed off for his portfolio. He has never seen one put in before but has read around the subject.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
It used to be said that for procedures 'see one, do one, teach one'. These days have long gone. Doctors are now expected to show proof of competency before performing procedures alone. In this scenario the F2 doctor has never seen one previously so it is not appropriate for him to insert the drain today. The best option is for him to watch you.

If you are going to let the F2 doctor insert the drain you should be honest with the patient about his lack of experience.

Signing him off without seeing him perform the procedure is a very poor option which could result in a GMC referral if found out. It also puts future patients at risk

Letting him insert the drain today without supervision is again a very poor option as it puts the patient at risk.

questions:
You are a junior doctor working on a Care of the Elderly Ward. You are well acquainted with one patient, Jack, who is frail and has had several recent admissions with chest infections. Although his current infection is not life-threatening, he is failing to respond to treatment adequately and is increasingly frail.

The locum consultant asks you to speak to Jack about resuscitation, given that you are the member of the team who knows Jack best. You remember that last week, Jack's wife approached you and told you that Jack is beginning to tire of being in hospital and just wants to get home.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
Discussing 'Do Not Attempt Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (DNACPR)' orders is a common role of a junior doctor and one that is appropriate for any junior doctor who knows the patient and feels competent to have the discussion. In this scenario, it would therefore be appropriate for you to undertake this discussion. The GMC discuss DNACPR decisions in Treatment and care towards the end of life: good practice in decision making. They are clear that discussions should involve the patient and those close to them and that these discussions should revolve around the wishes of the patient. The most appropriate option is therefore ask the patient if you can have a discussion about their treatment goals with them with their family present. This involves the patient and their relatives in the decision-making process.

Ask the patient if they have had any thoughts about resuscitation is less appropriate as it does not include those close to the patient. Also, this conversation does not involve the patient's greater wishes around their care. This phrasing is blunt and may shock and upset the patient. A more natural conversation around the patient's ongoing care which then leads to resuscitation decisions is more appropriate.

Advise the consultant that, as the most senior member of the team, it is more appropriate for them to have this discussion is not necessary unless you feel inadequately skilled to effectively have this conversation with the patient. Being able to discuss resuscitation with patients is a key skill of any doctor, and the most appropriate healthcare professional to discuss resuscitation with the patient is often the one who knows them most well, not necessarily the most senior. It is clear from the brief that you know the patient and their family, and in fact, you already have some understanding - through the patient's wife - of his thoughts towards his treatment. It would be appropriate for you to discuss resuscitation with the patient but to involve your seniors if there were any concerns or disagreements raised in this discussion, or if the patient or family wanted to speak with a senior. Junior doctors who are fully registered (i.e. doctors above F1 level) can also sign DNACPR forms, but a senior doctor needs to countersign them within 24 hours.

Sign a 'Do Not Resusicate' form and explain to the patient why you have done this is inappropriate as it does not include involving the patient and their relatives in the decision-making process. Whilst giving cardiopulmonary resuscitation is a clinical decision that the medical team are not obliged to make, it is bad practice to make and document this decision without involving the patient and their relatives. This is not the worst option, however, as it does not involve keeping the decision from the patient.

Sign a 'Do Not Resuscitate' form but do not tell the patient to avoid upsetting them is the worst option as it involves making a resuscitation decision without the input of the patient and their relatives and also involves withholding the decision from the patient. There may be times when discussion about resuscitation with a patient with capacity is inappropriate - for example if they have expressed that they would find this too upsetting. There is no evidence that this is relevant to this case though. Furthermore, in these examples, the GMC state that you should seek the patient's permission to discuss this information with those close to them.
question:
You are a junior doctor working on a Care of the Elderly Ward. You are well acquainted with one patient, Jack, who is frail and has had several recent admissions with chest infections. Although his current infection is not life-threatening, he is failing to respond to treatment adequately and is increasingly frail.

The locum consultant asks you to speak to Jack about resuscitation, given that you are the member of the team who knows Jack best. You remember that last week, Jack's wife approached you and told you that Jack is beginning to tire of being in hospital and just wants to get home.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
question_notes:
Discussing 'Do Not Attempt Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (DNACPR)' orders is a common role of a junior doctor and one that is appropriate for any junior doctor who knows the patient and feels competent to have the discussion. In this scenario, it would therefore be appropriate for you to undertake this discussion. The GMC discuss DNACPR decisions in Treatment and care towards the end of life: good practice in decision making. They are clear that discussions should involve the patient and those close to them and that these discussions should revolve around the wishes of the patient. The most appropriate option is therefore ask the patient if you can have a discussion about their treatment goals with them with their family present. This involves the patient and their relatives in the decision-making process.

Ask the patient if they have had any thoughts about resuscitation is less appropriate as it does not include those close to the patient. Also, this conversation does not involve the patient's greater wishes around their care. This phrasing is blunt and may shock and upset the patient. A more natural conversation around the patient's ongoing care which then leads to resuscitation decisions is more appropriate.

Advise the consultant that, as the most senior member of the team, it is more appropriate for them to have this discussion is not necessary unless you feel inadequately skilled to effectively have this conversation with the patient. Being able to discuss resuscitation with patients is a key skill of any doctor, and the most appropriate healthcare professional to discuss resuscitation with the patient is often the one who knows them most well, not necessarily the most senior. It is clear from the brief that you know the patient and their family, and in fact, you already have some understanding - through the patient's wife - of his thoughts towards his treatment. It would be appropriate for you to discuss resuscitation with the patient but to involve your seniors if there were any concerns or disagreements raised in this discussion, or if the patient or family wanted to speak with a senior. Junior doctors who are fully registered (i.e. doctors above F1 level) can also sign DNACPR forms, but a senior doctor needs to countersign them within 24 hours.

Sign a 'Do Not Resusicate' form and explain to the patient why you have done this is inappropriate as it does not include involving the patient and their relatives in the decision-making process. There is no evidence that this is relevant to this case though. Furthermore, in these examples, the GMC state that you should seek the patient's permission to discuss this information with those close to them.
title: GMC: Treatment and care towards the end of life - Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)
body:
CPR stands for cardiopulmonary resuscitation. The purpose of CPR is to maintain adequate oxygenation of the blood and to restore the circulation in a person's who's heart has stopped pumping. This is known as a cardiac arrest. CPR is taught across the country to a wide range of people, from healthcare novices to experienced professionals. The process involves a series of chest compressions and mouth-to-mouth rescue breaths. If available, a defibrillator is also used to provide stimulation to the heart via electrical shocks.

CPR is recognised as an invasive procedure which is a physical burden, especially for a more fragile patient. For example, it would not be unusual to break multiple ribs whilst doing proper chest compressions. CPR is more effective in the right circumstances, and can prolong the oxygenation of brain tissue whilst professionals try to reverse the cause of the cardiac arrest. This reduces the risk of negative sequelae such as long-term cognitive impairment and physical disability.

However, CPR generally has a relatively low success rate, especially in patients with multiple comorbidities. Do not attempt CPR (DNACPR) discussions are encouraged in patients that are unlikely to recover if a cardiac arrest was to take place. This is to ensure death does not occur in an undignified manner, which can be unnecessarily traumatic for the patient and their family.


When to consider making a DNACPR decision

Although DNACPR decisions ultimately lie in the hands of the medical team, they should be discussed with the patient and their family (if appropriate). These discussions should explain:
  • what CPR involves
  • that it is unlikely to be successful in this patient and why
  • that if a patient's condition improves, the DNACPR can be re-discussed and revoked
  • that a DNACPR form does not mean that a patient will not be treated from then on, it simply means that CPR will not be attempted
  • that the aim of the DNACPR is to give patients and their families more agency over their death and to prevent death in an undignified manner
  • that having a DNACPR can increase the chances of the patient being able to pass away in their preferred place of death e.g. at home.

Even if CPR is likely to be successful, it is not always appropriate. As mentioned previously, CPR can cause trauma to the patient as well as long-term negative sequelae, and it is not guaranteed that the patient will recover to their former level of functioning. In these scenarios, it is vital to weigh up the risks and benefits of CPR and discuss these with the patient. As with any medical treatment or intervention, if a patient has the capacity and is fully informed of the CPR process, they have the right to refuse it with an advanced decision. This is regardless of whether the medical team deem CPR to be an appropriate intervention.

Conversely, if a patient lacks capacity, the medical team may decide that CPR is not in the patient's best interests and a DNACPR will be put in place. It is important to identify potential DNACPR patients early to ensure that the relevant documentation is completed and disseminated, as well as allowing time to have these important discussions with the patient and their family. This is especially important if a patient is admitted to hospital when they are acutely unwell and a potential cardiac or respiratory arrest is likely.


Discussions about whether to attempt CPR

As previously mentioned, a decision on the appropriateness of CPR should be made with the patient, their family and with other healthcare professionals. To do this you must:
  • approach discussions sensitively
  • remember that some patients, or their relatives, may have preconceived notions of what a DNACPR means and involves. They may need educating on this matter
  • assess the patient's capacity to make decisions about CPR. If the patient lacks capacity, you must discuss the likely effectiveness of CPR with other healthcare professionals and weigh up the risks and benefits for the patient


When DNACPR will not be successful

If the medical team have decided that a cardiac or respiratory arrest is likely, but CPR is unlikely to be effective and may cause unnecessary trauma, you must decide whether to inform the patient of the DNACPR decision. Some patients may want to know this information, whilst others may prefer to remain ignorant. You should carefully explore the patient's ideas and expectations regarding this area of their care to determine the level of information they want to know. It is then their leading clinician's responsibility to inform them to an appropriate level. This also involves answering any questions they may have, regardless of whether this is a difficult conversation to have. If your patient wants to remain ignorant of this information, you should seek permission to share this information with their next of kin and relevant family members. This is the same for patients that lack capacity. You should also inform any legal proxy involved with these patients.


When CPR may be successful

If the healthcare team determines that CPR may be effective in a patient, the benefits of prolonging their life (and the quality of this life) must be weighed against the risks of CPR. This discussion can include the patient, and they should be offered the opportunity to voice their opinion on this matter and ask any questions that they may have. This is a sensitive topic and must be done by the right people, at the right time and in the right environment. Even with the right circumstances, some patients may not want to be involved in this discussion, and that's ok. However, if they do want to be involved you must inform them of the likely outcomes of CPR, the risks involved in the procedure and an explanation about the potential need for other invasive treatments as a result of successful CPR e.g. ventilation. In some cases, these additional invasive treatments may not be deemed appropriate, despite successful CPR. The patient should be informed of the opinion of the healthcare team regarding the likelihood of success of CPR.

There are some patients who wish to receive CPR despite there only being a small chance of success. This is despite being informed of the risks of CPR and the opinions of the healthcare team. In these cases, you must ensure that the patient has definitely been adequately informed of the risks of CPR, their likely level of recovery and length of possible survival. If they still want to have CPR, you should discuss the reasons for the request and try to come to a compromise. For example, in some patients, you may be able to agree on limited CPR interventions if the need ever arose. However, if the healthcare team decide that CPR is in no way clinically appropriate, you are not obliged to agree to attempt CPR. This is ultimately a medical decision. However, the patient should be informed of this and they should be given an explanation as to why this is the case. They are allowed to seek a second opinion if they wish. When the benefits versus the risks are very similar, the patient normally has the final decision.

As is standard in decisions regarding medical treatment in patients that don't have capacity, the following guidance applies:
  • you should first attempt to consult the patient's relevant legal proxy. This is the person that is legally chosen to make medical decisions for the patient
  • if there is no legal proxy, you must discuss the decision with the patient's next of kin and relevant close family members
  • during these discussions, you must make the relevant parties aware of the role that they are playing in this discussion. If they are not a legal proxy, their role is to advise the healthcare team of what they believe would be the choice of the patient. However, it is not their decision to decide whether CPR is the appropriate clinical decision
  • these parties must be informed of the same information about CPR regarding risks, likelihood of success and potential level of disability after the CPR.
  • if the legal proxy decides that they wish the patient to received CPR despite a low chance of success, the same rules apply as in the previous paragraph. You must explore these decisions, attempt to reach a consensus or a compromise, and if this is not possible, explain to them that you are not obliged to carry out CPR in this case. They also have a right to seek a second opinion


Resolving disagreements

If there is a disagreement about a DNACPR order, the healthcare team should attempt to resolve it to the best of their ability. If this is not possible, legal frameworks should be consulted and advice should be sought.


Recording and communicating CPR decisions

Any discussions regarding DNACPR with a patient, their legal proxy or those close to them should be recorded in the patient notes. Any decisions should be written as an advance care plan, and the relevant DNACPR forms should be completed.


Treatment and care after a DNACPR decision

It must be explicit to the patient, the family and the healthcare team that a DNACPR order solely refers to CPR and does not impact on the initiation of any other treatments, medications or interventions. Decisions regarding this aspect of the patient's care will be decided as a separate issue with its own set of discussions.

A DNACPR decision does not override clinical judgement if a cardiac or respiratory arrest occurs from an unexpected source e.g. due to the induction of anaesthesia. These circumstances are reversible and not due to overall health status or comorbidity, and were not planned or discussed during the DNACPR decision.

Emergencies and CPR

If cardiac or respiratory arrest occurs in an unexpected circumstance, e.g. an emergency, then there is often times when no DNACPR discussion has taken place, and no decision has been made. In this case, CPR should be attempted unless there is sufficient information to suggest that it will most likely not be successful.

options: Agree with Maria that the patient was challenging and provoked a response
Ensure that the patient is not distressed by the encounter
Speak to the nurse in charge about Maria's behaviour
Approach Maria when she is calm and discuss what you observed with her, offering to help
Show empathy towards your colleague and ask her if there is anything troubling her
Speak to the other F2's and staff on the ward about what you saw
Raise your concerns with the nursing and midwifery council
Speak to your clinical supervisor
questions:
You are a F2 working in a Geriatric ward. You see Maria, a respected nurse, shout at one of her patients with dementia and mutter obscenities under her breath. She then storms out of the ward and is not seen for the next 15 minutes. This is the first time you have witnessed this behaviour and it seems out of character for Maria.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The correct options are 2, 4 and 5. This scenario addresses challenging unprofessional behaviour as well as showing empathy and support towards your fellow colleague. It is important that you ensure that the patient is ok and not distressed by the encounter (option 2). Approaching Maria when she is calm to discuss the situation (option 4) and trying to identify what caused her outburst (option 5) shows empathy and support towards a colleague who may be struggling.

It is always best to speak to your colleague first before escalating to their senior (option 3) or to your senior (option 8). Speaking to the other F2's and staff is unnecessary and may lead to gossip (option 6). Informing the nursing and midwifery council is an overreaction for a first and otherwise isolated incident (option 7). Colluding with Maria that the patient was challenging is incorrect (option 1) and does not address the issue.

Remember, the 3 best answers out of 8 have to form a coherent answer together. Think of this as option 2 AND option 4 AND option 5. If they do not go together as a pack, then one or more of the answers are likely to be incorrect.

See the GMC guidelines on supporting colleagues in the workplace here: http://www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/goodmedicalpractice/teachingtraining.asp
